awd_titl_txt: Creating a State-Level Public Opinion Data Base for Law and Courts Scholarship: New Frontiers in Research on the Public's Views of Third Branch Politics
awd_abstract_narration:
Social scientists know at least two important things about law and politics in the United States. First, public opinion matters. What the public prefers - and what it will tolerate - is an important element of many aspects of law and politics, as in the support the public is willing to extend to legal institutions, especially when they make unpopular decisions. Second, states matter. The U.S. is a federal system, so states always matter. But when it comes to law, the vast majority of legal activity takes place in the individual states. It follows, therefore, that public opinion in each of the American states is important.

However, in the social sciences, the large survey data bases have been far more concerned with ordinary politics (primarily electoral), rather than law and politics, and therefore have not surveyed the American people on issues relevant to those concerned with law and politics.

This project will produce a state public opinion data base on this topic that can be used by scholars of widely varying theoretical foci. Marrying a newly developed statistical methodology that can derive state-level estimates from national survey data to an existing survey data base focused on legal matters, this project promises to create a treasure-trove of measures of how the residents of individual states feel about numerous issues of law and politics. For instance, this project will allow the assessment of whether the methods of selecting and retaining judges in the American states have any consequences for public attitudes toward law and courts. By creating and disseminating state-level measures of public opinion on law and legal institutions, this project will stimulate new efforts to understand the relationships between the judiciaries and their constituents, the people of the American states.

por.por_cntn:
The United States is a federal political system. Nowhere is this more important than in the dual systems of federal and state legal institutions. Scholars have determined that courts are dependent upon support from the mass public – their constituents – for their effectiveness, but nearly all of that research focuses on the federal, not state, courts. This project harnesses a newly developed methodology that allows estimates of public opinion within individual states to be drawn from nationally representative samples, thus allowing us to construct measures of the degree to which citizens grant legitimacy to both their state and federal courts.

For instance, in this research, we develop measures of the legitimacy of the U.S. Supreme Court within each of the states, allowing us to investigate where legitimacy is especially high and especially low. Our findings reveal a very strong relationship between U.S. Supreme Court legitimacy and region: legitimacy is markedly lower in the southern states. For instance, of all the states, the people of Mississippi are the least supportive of the U.S. Supreme Court. Quite surprisingly, we find no evidence that citizens choose whether to extend legitimacy to their own state supreme court or the U.S. Supreme Court – no relationship (positive or negative) exists between the legitimacy of the state and federal courts. For instance, the people of Alabama extend relatively low support to the U.S. Supreme Court, but they are also not very supportive of the Alabama Supreme Court. Contrariwise, Texans are quite supportive of their state supreme court, but not so supportive of the U.S. Supreme Court. This suggests that support for courts depends in part on which specific courts are under consideration; attitudes toward state and federal institutions are differentiated. Given the many conflicts between state high courts and the U.S. Supreme Court – for example, Caperton v. Massey, in which the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that the West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals had acted in a fashion that caused people to view it as unfair and partial – the relative legitimacy people extend to state and federal judicial institutions can be of great practical significance. Finally, we are continuing to explore the interconnections of these attitudes toward legal institutions and the more fundamental legal and political cultures of the American states.
